Problem:
Given a complex function \\( z(t) \\) governed by the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\), where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( \\omega \\) a real constant. We examine the effect of applying the Fourier transform \( \\mathcal{F} \\) on the function \\( z(t) \\).

By observing the Fourier transform of \\( z(t) \\) at any time \\( t \\), is it possible to uniquely identify the initial value \\( z_0 \\) without knowing \\( t \\) at which the Fourier transform was applied?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of \\( z(t) \\) focuses exclusively on frequency components and does not retain phase information specific to the value of \\( t \\). Since \\( z(t) = e^{i\\omega t}z_0 \\) alters phase over time but retains the same frequency components, the initial value \\( z_0 \\), especially its phase relative to time, cannot be uniquely determined without additional information about \\( t \\).
